questions.text: A 49-year-old man suffered chest pain, not relieved by exercise or bending forward, palpitations and diaphoresis. Upon bringing him to the ER, his ECG was performed, which was consistent with STEMI. His troponin levels were within normal limits. Thus, stable angina was suspected and angiography was done. It revealed 80% occlusion in Left Ascending Artery (LAD). The cardiologist recommended him to undergo an angioplasty and for a drug coated stent to be placed to prevent re-occlusion. The stent was coated with a drug called sirolimus. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
• The above question describes Stable angina with critical stenosis in LAD. in such cases, when drug eluting stents are placed, Sirolimus coated stents prevent restenosis.
  • Sirolimus suppressant is a macrolide antibiotic (like tacrolimus), which was earlier named Rapamycin. It binds to the same immunophilin FKBP as tacrolimus, but the sirolimus-FKBP complex inhibits another kinase called ‘mammalian target of rapamycin'(mTOR), and does not interact with calcineurin (Fig. 65.2). The kinase mTOR is an important link in the cascade of signaling pathways which lead to proliferation and differentiation of T-cells activated by IL-2 and other cytokines.
  • Other options-
  • calcineurin inhibitors are cyclosporine and tacrolimus
  • Antimetabolite as immunosuppressant is Azathioprine
  • IL-1 receptor antagonist is Anakinra.

Reference:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 941

questions.text: A patient with cardiac insufficiency is prescribed Enalapril, Torsemide, spironolactone, metoprolol and rosuvastatin. When the patient came for follow-up, his ECG showed tall peaked T waves and S. potassium levels were 5.6mmol/L. An interaction of which 2 drugs can cause this metabolic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Interactions of drugs when given along with ACE inhibitors

  • Diuretics synergise with the hypotensive action of ACE inhibitors by depleting Na+ and raising renin levels. In diuretic treated patients, the starting dose of ACE inhibitors should be low.
  • Indomethacin (and other NSAIDs) attenuate the hypotensive action by retaining salt and water. Incidents of renal failure have been reported when a NSAID was given to patients (especially elderly) receiving ACE inhibitor + diuretic.
  • Hyperkalaemia can occur if K+ supplements/ K+ sparing diuretics are given with any ACE inhibitor.
  • Antacids reduce bioavailability of captopril.
  • ACE inhibitors reduce Li+ clearance and predispose to its toxicity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 531-532

questions.text: A 54-year-old male with a sedentary lifestyle came for a follow-up of hypertension. He was previously prescribed Valsartan and Nifedipine, but currently, his BP is not controlled with these medications. The doctor decided to prescribe a third first line drug, Chlorothiazide. Which electrolyte abnormality is observed with the drug furosemide, which is not seen with thiazides?
questions.solution:
• Loop diuretics by inhibiting Na-K-2Cl pump also inhibit paracellular transport of Ca and Mg and thus cause hypercalciuria and hypermagnesiuria, thus it is also used in hypercalcemia of malignancy.
  • Thiazides on the other hand cause hypocalciuria and thus it can be used for treating concurrent hypertension and osteoporosis. Both these diuretics cause hypokalemia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 627

choices.text: Causes pulmonary fibrosis by damaging type-1 pneumocytes
Causes hypotension due to alpha blockade

questions.text: A patient presents with ocular findings as shown below. Which of the following is incorrect with respect to the antiarrhythmic drug causing it?
questions.solution:
• The image shows cornea verticillate, a known side effect of class-3 antiarrhythmic Amiodarone.
  • Amiodarone causes pulmonary fibrosis by damaging type-2 pneumocytes, which is treated with Prednisolone. Type -1 pneumocytes are damaged by Bleomycin.
  • Amiodarone can cause digoxin toxicity by inhibiting p-gp, which causes efflux of digoxin and this terminates its action.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 578

questions.text: One of the oral inotropic agents given for CHF acts by inhibiting the Na-K pump, thus leading to an increase in intracellular Ca2+ and increasing the contractility of heart. Which of the following conditions on ECG would be an absolute contraindication to its administration?
questions.solution:
• The given drug is Digoxin.
  • Ventricular tachycardia: digitalis is contraindicated because it may precipitate ventricular fibrillation.
  • Partial A-V block: may be converted to complete A­V block by digoxin.
  • Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome: Digoxin is con­traindicated because it decreases the ERP of bypass tract in 1/3 patients. In them rapid atrial impulses may be transmitted to ventricles → VF may occur. Digoxin can increase the chances of reentry by slowing conduction in normal AV bundle and accelerating it in aberrant pathway.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 561

questions.text: A 56-year-old male who is a chronic smoker and an alcoholic is taking a combination of optimum doses of Valsartan, Nifedipine and Chlorothiazide. Despite this treatment and adequate compliance to therapy, his BP on follow-up is 142/82 mmHg. A diagnosis of resistant hypertension is made. Which drug can be added next to his prescription, given that his Serum Potassium levels are 4 mmol/L?
questions.solution:
• Patients who do not achieve target BP even when taking optimal doses of 3 drugs are regarded as having resistant hypertension. Many patients having diabetes and/or CKD fall in this category.
  • In such cases the NICE recommend adding a fourth drug, which can either be an aldosterone antagonist (if serum K+ is <4.5 mmol/L) or higher dose of the thiazide (if serum K+ is >4.5 mmol/L) or a b blocker (especially b blocker with vasodilating property, viz. carvedilol, nebivolol) or a selective a1 blocker.
  • Captopril cannot be given in this case since an ARB is already being given and a combination of ACE-Inhibitors and ARB is avoided.

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 616

questions.text: Mr. Mahesh is a 47-year-old on Perindopril for hypertension. On follow-up after 4 weeks, his BP is 130/82 mmHg, but he reports a dry brassy cough for 2 weeks. He also has a history of hypercholesterolemia for which he is on Atorvastatin. He requests the doctor to prescribe him another medication since his cough is persistent. By which mechanism is the patient experiencing this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• ACE-Inhibitors exert their antihypertensive action by inhibiting AT-2 and thus disrupting the RAAS axis, causing vasodilatation. It causes a greater fall in BP in hyperreninemic states.
  • One of its side effects is a dry, persistent brassy cough that develops 1-8 weeks after starting the medication and stops 4-6 days after stopping the drug. This is seen because ACE-Inhibitors also inhibit enzymes degrading Bradykinin and Substance P.
  • ACE-Inhibitors do not have interactions with Statins

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 531

questions.text:
Mr. Paritosh presented to the emergency with chest pain at rest,not relieved by medication.It started 40 minutes ago with a feeling of heaviness and later progressed to retrosternal pain that radiated to the jaw. The patient came with his fist clenched to his chest.He was diaphoretic and tachypneic. His medical history is significant for dyslipidemia, for which he was on Tab. Atorvastatin but his wife reported poor diet and compliance to therapy. His vitals are as follows
Temperature-97.5F,
Pulse- 155 bpm,
RR-19/min,
BP- 90/60 mm HG and O2 saturation- 79% on room air.Suspecting IHD,his ECG was done after resuscitating him, which is shown below.His ECG is given below. His Cardiac troponin levels were 20ng/L(normal-14ng/L). Considering the diagnosis, which of the following drug therapy will you not consider for this patient
?
questions.solution:
• The clinical vignette along with the ECG showing ST depression inlead II, III, aVF, aVL, V3, V2, V4 and V6 with reciprocal ST elevation shows NSTEMI. The cornerstone for, management of an acute attack of NSTEMI is
  1. Morphine
  2. Oxygen
  3. NTG
  4. Aspirin
  5. IV beta blockers
  6. LMWH
  7. Abciximab
  • ;Thrombolysis in form of reteplase should not be done for NSTEMI because-
  • In unstable angina mechanical obstruction in the form of plaque fissure/rupture is more common than completely occluding thrombus. So, lysis becomes less important.
  • Even if the thrombus is present, it is often intra plaque or intra lesional and the luminal projection of thrombus is reduced and hence thrombolytic agents have limited area to act.
  • Further in UA/NSTEMI since it is a slow and gradual occlusion (Unlike sudden & total occlusion in STEMI) the platelets get marginalized and trapped within the plaque. Hence in UA thrombus is predominantly white. Often, a central platelet core is seen over which fibrin clot may also be formed.
  • All available thrombolytic agents act basically as a fibrinolytic agent, and so it finds difficult to lyse the platelet rich clot. There is also a small risk of these agents lysing the fibrin cap and exposing underlying platelet core and trigger a fresh thrombus. This has been documented in many trials (TIMI 3b to be specific) So if we thrombolyse in UA, there could be a risk of recurrent ACS episodes in the post thrombolytic phase.
  • UA is a semi emergency where there is no race against time to salvage myocardium. Administering a stroke prone thrombolytic agent tilts the risk benefit ratio against it.
  • Among UA, there is a significant group of secondary /perioperative UA due to increased demand situations. Here there is absolutely no role for any thrombolytic agents, the simple reason is, there is no thrombus to get lysed.
  • Many of the UA patient have multivessel CAD and might require surgical re-vascularization directly.
  • Long term management of NSTEMI is along the lines of Stable angina and drugs having mortality benefit, such as Aspirin, Statins, ACEI, Beta blockers are preferred

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 603

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was on oral isosorbide mononitrate therapy for Classical angina, of which he had 1 attack 2 year ago. Recently he has been reporting a reduced libido and troubles getting an erection. No functional cause for the same was found. Which class of drug will you not prescribe to this patient?
questions.solution:
• The clinical features suggest Erectile dysfunction. The drug of choice for ED is PDE-5 inhibitors, such as Sildenafil and Tadalafil. Sildenafil and other PDE­5 in­hibitors cause dangerous potentiation of nitrate action: severe hypotension, MI and deaths are on record.
  • This is because Nitrates are cGMP stimulators, which are metabolized by PDE-5. If PDE-5 inhibitors such as Sildenafil are given, additive hypotension due to excessive vasodilation may be seen. Thus, sildenafil is avoided in Erectile Dysfunction when the patient is on Nitrate therapy
  • Androgens and PIPE have not been reported to cause similar interactions with nitrates
  • PDE-4 inhibitors are not prescribed for ED.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 588

choices.text: It crosses the blood brain barrier
It can also be used for the treatment of paralytic ileus

questions.text: A 23-year-old was posted for an elective internal fixation surgery for fracture of shaft of humerus under general anesthesia. The muscle relaxant pancuronium was used for her. Towards the end of the surgery, a particular drug was injected and immediately the relaxation effects were abolished. Which of the following cannot be true for this drug?
questions.solution:
• Neostigmine is preferred for the treatment of myasthenia gravis. It does not produce adverse effects in the CNS (does not cross BBB) and it also has direct NM receptor agonistic action.
  • It can also be used for the treatment of cobra bite (cobra venom contain the compounds that cause skeletal muscle paralysis), post operative paralytic ileus, atony of urinary bladder and the reversal of competitive skeletal muscle relaxants.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 122

choices.text: Inhibition of atropine's action by digitalis

questions.text: A patient of symptomatic Acute CHF was on digoxin therapy. 2 days later he developed AV block. Atropine was administered immediately to counteract the bradycardia. However, initially the patient's heart rate increased from 50 to 32 bpm and later stabilized to 73 bpm. What could be the reason for the initial bradycardia?
questions.solution:
• Atropine is the drug of choice for brady-arrhythmias caused by Digoxin or AV block.
  • Atropine causes bradycardia initially due to inhibition of presynaptic muscarinic receptors (M1) but further increase in dose causes tachycardia due to inhibition of post-synaptic M2 receptors.
  • This is suggested by the finding that selective M1 antagonist pirenzepine is equipotent to atropine in causing bradycardia. Moreover, atropine substitutes which do not cross blood­ brain barrier also produce initial bradycardia.
  • Atropine abbreviates refractory period of AV node and facilitates AV conduction, especially if it has been depressed by high vagal tone. P­R interval is shortened. It has negligible effect on BP and cardiac contractility.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 125

questions.text: A patient of schizophrenia on haloperidol presented with mask like facies, pin rolling tremors and cogwheel rigidity. Which drug can antagonize these effects?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of extrapyramidal side effects caused by D2 blockers.
  • Centrally acting anticholinergics, namely synthetic compounds such as Trihexyphenidyl, procyclidine and Biperidine can be used for drug induced parkinsonism.
  • D2 blockers such as typical antipsychotics reduce dopamine levels in CNS, leading to Parkinson- like features. These can be counteracted by an equal reduction in Acetylcholine, which is produced by these synthetic anticholinergics.
  • Tiotropium is a semi synthetic anticholinergic used as a bronchodilator in COPD
  • Terazosin is an alpha-1 selective antagonist used in the treatment of BPH
  • Tropicamide is a mydriatic used for fundoscopy as well as refractive error testing

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 460

questions.text: A 64-year-old man on treatment for BPH was prescribed Tamsulosin. He was also taking Metoprolol, Atorvastatin and Sitagliptin. Of late he was complaining of gradual painless loss of vision. A diagnosis of cataract was made and he was scheduled for a phacoemulsification along with IOL implantation. Which of the following drugs will have to be stopped prior to surgery?
questions.solution:
• Tamsulosin is a relatively uroselective α1A/α1D blocker (α1A : α1B affinity 7-38 fold) and has been found as effective as terazosin in improving BHP symptoms, because α1A subtype predominate in the bladder base and prostate.
  • Tamsulosin does not cause significant changes in BP or HR at doses which relieve urinary symptoms, and it is not used as an antihypertensive.
  • No increase in adverse cardiovascular events has been noted after prolonged use. Postural hypotension is infrequent, dizziness and retrograde ejaculation are the only significant side effects.
  • Problem of floppy iris has been encountered during cataract surgery in patients taking tamsulosin. Thus, it is stopped before ocular surgeries

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 156

questions.text: A 7-month-old child has the following lesion since birth. It is red, fleshy and has not progressed since its appearance. Which of the following drugs acting on the nervous system is useful for the same?
questions.solution:
• The above image shows Infantile hemangiomas, which are the most common benign tumors of infancy. The majority of hemangiomas are located in the head and neck region with lesions on the trunk and extremities being less common. Whilst most hemangioma are non-problematic, requiring no treatment, approximately 10% cause significant morbidity predominantly through airway obstruction, ocular compression, functional impairment or ulceration.
  • Propranolol and timolol are nonselective β adrenergic antagonists traditionally used for cardiovascular disease. These agents are also effective in treating infantile hemangiomas and have become the preferred treatment of infantile hemangiomas requiring intervention.
  • Topical timolol drops and gel-forming solution are available but do not adequately treat deeper lesions.
  • Other options-
    • Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist used for the treatment of xerostomia and acute angle closure glaucoma
    • Yohimbine is a selective alpha-2 antagonist which can be used for diabetic neuropathy
    • Mirabegron is a selective beta-3 agonist used for overactive bladder.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 1500

questions.text: A 21-year-old girl with complains of menorrhagia and back pain was diagnosed with uterine fibroids during TVS. these fibroids were submucosal, 5x4cm and 2 in number. She was prescribed nafarelin nasal spray to reduce the size of the fibroids to afford symptomatic relief to the patient. Long term therapy with these agents poses a risk for all of the following except?
questions.solution:
• Nafarelin is a long-acting GnRH agonist, which is 150 times more potent than natural GnRH.
  • Uses are:
  • Assisted reproduction: Endogenous LH surge needs to be suppressed when controlled ovarian stimulation is attempted by exogenous FSH and LH injection, so that precisely timed mature oocytes can be harvested. This is achieved by 400 μg BD intranasal nafarelin, reduced to 200 μg BD when menstrual bleeding occurs.
  • Uterine fibroids: Nafarelin 200 μg BD intra­ nasal for 3-6 months can reduce the size of leiomyoma and afford symptomatic relief.
  • Endometriosis: 200 μg in alternate nostril BD for up to 6 months. It is as effective as danazol, but second course cannot be given due to risk of osteoporosis.
  • Central precocious puberty: 800 μg BD by nasal spray; breast and genital development is arrested in girls and boys. Treatment is generally carried out till the age of 11 years in girls or 12 years in boys. The effect is reversible; pubertal changes resume when therapy is discontinued.
  • Adverse effects: Hot flashes, loss of libido, vaginal dryness, osteoporosis, emotional lability.
  • It does not cause breast cancer, instead it is used for ER positive breast cancer

Reference:- Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 264

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented to the emergency department with vomiting, hyperventilation and tachycardia. Her orientation was impaired. On examination, her heart rate was 152bpm, BP 100/72 mmHg and there was a fruity smell coming from her mouth. Her random blood glucose was 840mg/dL. Her father revealed that she was diabetic since 5 years and was on insulin therapy. Further, her elder brother was also diabetic from a young age. The girl had omitted her dose of insulin that day due to an overwhelming stress of her examinations. She was immediately admitted and was instituted with IV Insulin and NS. After checking the blood glucose at regular intervals, when blood glucose reached 300 mg/dL, an addition was made to her IV drip. Which of the following could it be?
questions.solution:
• The clinical vignette with diabetes mellitus from childhood and a family history for the same suggests type-1 diabetes. Thus, the clinical presentation of the patient could be due to Diabetes Ketoacidosis, which in turn was precipitated by stress and omission of insulin therapy.
  • Correction of dehydra­tion in DKA is vital. Normal saline is infused i.v., initially at the rate of 1 l/hr, reducing progressively to 0.5 l/4 hours depending on the volume status. Once BP and heart rate have stabilized and adequate renal perfusion is assured change over to 1⁄2N saline. After the blood sugar has reached 300 mg/dl, 5% glucose in 1⁄2N saline is the most appropriate fluid because blood glucose falls before ketones are fully cleared from the circulation. Also, glucose is needed to restore the depleted hepatic glycogen.
  • Other measures taken are-
  1. Iv insulin
  2. Kcl
  3. Sodium bicarbonate if acidosis persists
  4. Phosphate
  5. Antibiotics and control of precipitating factor.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 291

questions.text:
A 50-year-old patient was on treatment for Rheumatoid arthritis. Along with DMARDs, he was prescribed oral methylprednisolone. After a few years, he presented with the following findings

Which of the following steroids does not cause these findings?
questions.solution:
• The image above shows purple stria and abdominal obesity, which occurs due to glucocorticoid therapy. They cause Cushing Habitus, which is a characteristic appearance with rounded face, narrow mouth, supra- clavicular hump, obesity of trunk with relatively thin limbs.
  • Fragile skin, purple striae-typically on thighs and lower abdomen, easy bruising, telangiectasis, hirsutism. Cutaneous atrophy localized to the site occurs with topical application as well.

  • These occur with glucocorticoids, thus it is not seen with DOCA, since it is a pure mineralocorticoid.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 313

choices.text: It is the major circulating hormone
It has lesser risk of cardiac arrhythmias

questions.text: A 10-month child belonging to the Himalayan belt was brought by her mother with macroglossia, hypotonia, lagging developmental milestones and a coarse cry. Her mother had a history of hypothyroidism, for which she was taking l-thyroxine. The child's blood reports revealed hypothyroidism and accordingly, thyroxine was prescribed. Which of the following is incorrect about thyroxine?
questions.solution:
• Relation between T4 and T3
  • Thyroid secretes more T4 than T3, but in an iodine deficient state this difference is reduced.
  • T4 is the major circulating hormone because it is 15 times more tightly bound to plasma
  • T3 is 5 times more potent than T4 and acts faster. Peak effect of T3 comes in 1-2 days
  • while that of T4 takes 6–8 days.
  • T3 is more avidly bound to the nuclear receptor than T4 and the T4 Receptor complex is unable to activate/derepress gene transcription.
  • About 1/3 of T4 is converted to T3 in the thyroid cells, liver and kidney by type 1 deiodinase (D1) and released into circulation. In addition, T3 is generated within the target cells (skeletal muscle, heart, brain, pituitary) by another type (D2) of deiodinase.
  • Thus, it may be concluded that T3 is the active hormone, while T4 is mainly a transport form which functions as a prohormone of T3. However, it may directly produce some non-­ genomic actions.
  • Clinically, L-thyroxine is preferred over liothyronine for routine as well as urgent indications, because of more sustained and uniform action as well as lower risk of cardiac arrhythmias

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 272

choices.text: The female had forgotten to take a dose
The dosage for OCP's was wrong

questions.text: A 27-year-old female was on OCP pills as a method of contraception. She later developed an infection for which she was prescribed doxycycline. 1 month later, she presented with amenorrhea for 2 weeks and TVS revealed a gestational sac. She reported that she had been taking her OCP's as per schedule and claimed not to have missed a single dose. What could be the reason for this contraceptive failure?
questions.solution:
• Contraceptive failure may occur if the following drugs are used concurrently:

(a) Enzyme Inducers: phenytoin, phenobarbitone, primidone, carbamazepine, rifampin, ritonavir. Metabolism of estrogenic as well as progesterone component is increased.

(b) Suppression Of Intestinal Microflora: tetracyclines, ampicillin, etc. Deconjugation of estrogens excreted in bile fails to occur → their enterohepatic circulation is interrupted → blood levels fall.

  • With both types of interacting drugs, it is wise to switch over to a preparation containing 50 μg of ethinylestradiol or to use an alternative method of contraception. Rifampin is usually taken for a long time and is such a potent enzyme inducer that alternative contraception should be advised.

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 352

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman Yashee was posted for elective Cholecystectomy. Accordingly, she was prepared for surgery and prophylactic antibiotics were given. What would be the drug of choice for this surgical prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
• Cefazolin is the prototype first generation cephalosporin that is active against most Penicillin G sensitive organisms, i.e. Streptococci (pyogenes as well as viridians), gonococci, meningococci, C. diphtheriae, H. influenzae, clostridia and Actinomyces.
  • Activity against Klebsiella, Moraxella catarrhalis and E. coli is relatively high, but it is quite susceptible to staphylococcal β-lactamase. It can be given i.m. (mildly painful) as well as i.v. and has a longer t1⁄2 (2 hours) due to slower tubular secretion.
  • Cefazolin attains higher concentration in plasma and in bile. It is the preferred parenteral first-generation cephalosporin, especially for Surgical Prophylaxis.

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 776

questions.text: A 43-year-old Salim with Osteoarthritis was taking Indomethacin for 6 years. He recently came into contact with his wife Salma, who was a haj pilgrim and was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. As a contact, he was prescribed Ciprofloxacin and Paracetamol. Salim was also taking S-omeprazole for GERD. 24 hours later, he presented with convulsions and was immediately admitted. What could be the reason for his presentation?
questions.solution:
• NSAIDS are known to react adversely with fluoroquinolones and increase risk for their CNS toxicity. Other interactions of Fluoroquinolones are-
    • Plasma concentration of theophylline, caffeine and warfarin is increased by ciprofloxacin due to inhibition of metabolism: CNS toxicity can occur by concurrent use of theophylline and a FQ.
    • NSAIDs may enhance the CNS toxicity of FQs; seizures are reported.
    • Antacids, sucralfate and iron salts given together reduce absorption of FQs.

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 761

questions.text: Raji was a 25-year-old woman experiencing fever, dysuria, loin pain and urgency during micturition. Her WBC count was elevated to 14,000/mm3. Urine culture and microcopy revealed WBCs in urine as well as E. coli. She was prescribed antibiotics keeping UTI as a provisional diagnosis. However, her symptoms did not subside after 3 days and she was referred for a CT, which revealed cystitis. She was therefore prescribed a urinary analgesic to alleviate her symptoms. Which of the following could have been given?
questions.solution:
• Phenazopyridine is an orange dye which exerts analgesic action in the urinary tract and affords symptom­atic relief of burning sensation, dysuria and urgency due to cystitis.
  • It does not have antibacterial properties. Side effects are nausea and epigastric pain.

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 810

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presenting with fever, cough, night sweats and weight loss for 2 months was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. Accordingly, she was started on DOTS therapy. However, one week later she presented with the following findings, as well as complaints of nausea and vomiting. No hemolysis was observed. Her urine was also orange in color. What could be the reason behind this incident?
questions.solution:
• The clinical vignette along with orange urine suggests pseudojaundice, caused by Rifampicin.
  • It is an RNA polymerase inhibitor and is a first line drug for TB.
  • Other side effects are (Mnemonic- RIFAMPICIN)
    • Rash
    • Interstitial nephritis
    • Flu like illness
    • Anemia
    • Makes secretions reddish orange
    • Decreases platelets
    • Enzyme inducer
    • Contraceptive failure occurs
    • Deranged INR
  • The most common adverse effect is nausea and vomiting

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 819

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman positive for HIV delivered her first child by normal vaginal delivery. What class of drug is given for prophylaxis in the neonate?
questions.solution:
• Syrup Nevirapine is given for 6 weeks for prophylaxis in a neonate born to HIV positive mother.
  • These are nucleoside unrelated compounds which directly inhibit HIV reverse transcriptase without the need for intracellular phosphorylation.
  • Their locus of action on the enzyme is different from that of NRTIs, and they are non-competitive inhibitors.
  • They are more potent than AZT on HIV-1, but do not inhibit HIV-2.

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 872

questions.text:
A 31-year-old villager presented to the dermatology OPD with intense itching over his left hand for 2 days. He reports living in poor housing conditions. Examination revealed the following-

He was prescribed an oral tablet for the same, which is the only oral drug effective in this condition. By which mechanism does it kill the parasite implicated?
questions.solution:
• The image shows the classical burrows seen in scabies infection. The oral DOC for scabies is Ivermectin. Nematodes develop tonic paralysis when exposed to ivermectin.
  • It acts through a special type of glutamate gated Cl- channel found only in invertebrates. Such channels are not involved in the motor control of flukes and tapeworms which are unaffected by ivermectin.
  • Potentiation of GABAergic transmission in the worm has also been observed. The lack of GABA related actions in man could be due to its low affinity for mammalian GABA receptors and its exclusion from the brain by P-glycoprotein mediated efflux at the blood brain barrier.
  • Other options-
    • Albendazole causes microtubule inhibition. It is DOC for whipworm, roundworm, hook-worm, enterobius and Trichinella
    • Niclosamide inhibits oxidative phosphorylation. It is used for infection by cestodes
    • Praziquantel causes spastic paralysis and is used for cestode and trematode infection

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 911

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with follicular non-Hodgkin lymphoma undergoes chemotherapy. He develops suprapubic pain and hematuria. Which of the following compounds is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• This patient is most likely suffering from hemorrhagic cystitis secondary to cyclophosphamide administration. Hemorrhagic cystitis is a result of bladder damage by a toxic metabolite of cyclophosphamide (acrolein). Hemorrhagic cystitis due to cyclophosphamide administration can be prevented with the administration of Mesna.
  • Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic drug that covalently crosslinks DNA at the guanine N7 position. It is used for the treatment of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, breast cancer, ovarian cancer, and as an immunosuppressant. Its well-known side effects include hemorrhagic cystitis and myelosuppression.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 919-935

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of burning epigastric pain, dry cough, and occasional regurgitation. The pain is aggravated by eating and lying down. Physical examination shows a soft, non-tender abdomen. Upper endoscopy shows hyperemia in the distal third of the esophagus. Which of the following drugs is most likely to directly inhibit the common pathway of gastric acid secretion?
questions.solution:
• This patient presents with classical features of gastroesophageal reflux disease, e.g., heartburn that is aggravated by eating and lying down. ATP-dependent secretion of H+ ions into the gastric lumen is mediated by the H+/K+ ATPase located on gastric parietal cells and represents the common final pathway of gastric acid secretion.
  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) like lansoprazole are the first-line treatment for moderate to severe GERD. PPIs directly inhibit the H+/K+ ATPase, making them the most effective agents for the treatment of GERD.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 701

questions.text: A 36-year-old man has increasing levels of confusion for the past 6 hours. He drinks large amounts of alcohol daily and takes illegal drugs. He is disoriented. Physical examination shows jaundice, hepatomegaly, and scattered petechiae over the trunk and back. Neurologic examination shows flapping tremor. A drug with which of the following mechanism of action would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
• This patient has signs of liver failure (jaundice, petechiae, hepatomegaly) and a history of excessive drinking suggests alcoholic cirrhosis. Neurological features like confusion and flapping tremors indicate hepatic encephalopathy.
  • Hepatic encephalopathy is caused by the accumulation of toxic metabolites (predominantly ammonia) in the systemic circulation due to liver failure. Lactulose administered orally (or rectally) is converted to lactic acid in the intestine, leading to acidification in the gut and promoting the conversion of ammonia (NH3) to ammonium (NH4+).
  • Ammonium is not absorbed in the intestine and is instead excreted in feces, reducing the overall systemic load of ammonia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 725

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, Chaman Kumar, presents with history of chronic progressive dyspnea over the past five years. On examination, increased work of breathing is noted. The physician decides to start the patient on an additional medication that has both muco-active and anti-oxidative properties. What is the primary mechanism of action of this medication in the lungs?
questions.solution:
• The patient in this vignette presents with chronic dyspnea and a significant smoking history suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD). N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic and anti-oxidant drug used in COPD to loosen mucus plugs via disulfide bond cleavage.
  • N-acetylcysteine also has anti-oxidative and anti-inflammatory effects due to its metabolism into glutathione, an important anti-oxidative compound in the body.
  • As a result, N-acetylcysteine is also used to treat acetaminophen poisoning by regenerating glutathione and preventing the accumulation of NAPQI, a hepatotoxic metabolite of acetaminophen.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 238

questions.text: In patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, stimulation of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors results in an increase in mucus secretion, smooth muscle contraction and bronchoconstriction. The end result is an increase in airway resistance. Which of the following pharmacologic agents interferes directly with this pathway?
questions.solution:
• Anti-cholinergic agents such as ipratropium block the activation of muscarinic receptors and decrease airway resistance in these patients.
  • Ipratropium is an anticholinergic agent that blocks activation of the muscarinic acetylcholine receptors.
  • Muscarinic receptors are activated by acetylcholine resulting in an increase in cGMP formation and activation of subsequent downstream pathways.
  • Ipratropium is commonly used for the treatment of COPD and is often used in conjunction with other beta-adrenergic agonists such as albuterol.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 248

questions.text: An 82-year-old man is brought with slurred speech and unsteady with his footing. The patient is begun on IV tissue-plasminogen activator (tPA). Seven minutes after initiation of treatment, the patient becomes hypotensive and tachycardic. Shortly after he begins to vomit copious amounts of blood. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient has become suddenly hypotensive and tachycardic in the setting of initiation of thrombolytic agents. The antidote for thrombolytics include Aminocaproic acid or Tranexamic Acid.
  • tPA induced hemorrhage results from thrombolysis of hemostatic clots. Aminocaproic acid inhibits both the activation of plasminogen and the action of fibrinolysin (plasmin). Tranexamic acid, another antifibrinolytic, has also been used for hemorrhage secondary to tPA use.
  • The use of thrombolytics in the management of acute stroke requires careful patient selection. Initial rule out of a hemorrhagic stroke is done through non-contrast CT scan of the head. Patients that fall within the first 4.5 hours since symptom onset are candidates.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 676

questions.text: A 63-year-old man notices a strong cramping pain in his calves that consistently appears after a mile of walking. A diagnosis of peripheral artery disease with intermittent claudication is made. To improve his symptoms, cilostazol is prescribed. What is the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
• Cilostazol is a phosphodiesterase III inhibitor that leads to arterial vasodilation and decreased platelet aggregation. It is a first-line medication for the treatment of claudication caused by peripheral artery disease (PAD).
  • Cilostazol inhibits the activation of intracellular phosphodiesterase III. This leads to decreased breakdown of cAMP and subsequent increased cAMP concentrations in platelets and within the blood vessel walls.
  • This increased concentration of cAMP is thought to lead to decreased platelet aggregation and arterial vasodilation. According to the American Heart Association guidelines, cilostazol is a Class I recommended medication for the treatment of intermittent claudication.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 601-602

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with a history of hypertension presents to an outpatient office for regular check-up and is found to have hypertriglyceridemia. Her physician prescribes high-dose niacin and recommends taking the medication along with aspirin. The side effect the physician is trying to avoid is thought to be mediated by what mechanism?
questions.solution:
• The physician is likely worried about niacin-associated cutaneous flushing and pruritis. This is thought to be most likely caused by the drug-induced release of prostaglandins.
  • Niacin is a commonly prescribed medication used in hyperlipidemia. It is effective in reducing LDL and triglyceridemia while raising HDL. It does this by decreasing adipose tissue lipolysis and hepatic VLDL synthesis and secretion.
  • Its side effects include flushing, hyperglycemia, hyperuricemia, and pruritus. These side effects are thought to be caused by the niacin-induced release of prostaglandins and histamine. The flushing can often be prevented with the use of concurrent aspirin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 689

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes with a 6-month history of worsening involuntary movement of the left hand. She also reports that it takes her longer than usual to get up from a chair. Neurological examination shows difficulty initiating movement and a tremor in the left hand at rest. The tremor decreases when the patient is asked to draw a circle. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
• Bradykinesia and unilateral resting tremor ('pill-rolling tremor') that worsens with stress and improves with voluntary movement are consistent with Parkinson's disease.
  • A non-ergot dopamine agonist such as Pramipexole or Ropinirole is the typical first-line treatment for Parkinson's disease in young patients (< 65 years) without cognitive impairment.
  • If symptoms are severe, combination treatment of levodopa with carbidopa and/or a COMT inhibitor (e.g, entacapone) can be initiated. Levodopa is more effective than dopamine agonists. However, levodopa therapy is usually reserved for elderly patients or patients with cognitive impairment.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 457

questions.text: A 56-year-old man was diagnosed with a focal seizure and treatment with a drug that blocks voltage-gated sodium channels was begun. Today, he has noticed occasional double vision. His serum sodium is 132 mEq/L, alanine aminotransferase is 49 U/L, and aspartate aminotransferase is 46 U/L. This patient has most likely been taking which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
• Carbamazepine blocks voltage-gated sodium channels in neuronal membranes, which increases the seizure threshold and lowers neuronal excitability.
  • Carbamazepine is commonly used as first-line treatment for focal seizures but is associated with side effects, including diplopia, hepatotoxicity, and hyponatremia (probably due to associated SIADH), all of which are seen in this patient.
  • Other possible side effects include Stevens-Johnson syndrome, ataxia, CYP-450 induction, and blood count abnormalities (agranulocytosis, aplastic anemia).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 442

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. After evaluation, the physician recommends the administration of baclofen to the patient. This drug is most likely to improve which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Baclofen, a centrally acting γ-aminobutyric acid B (GABA-B) receptor agonist, exerts its effect on receptors in the brainstem and in the spinal cord's dorsal horn.
  • By activating the GABA-B receptors, Baclofen decreases excitatory neurotransmitter release and lessens γ motor neuron excitability, which improves spasticity, a common problem in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
  • In individuals with MS, spasticity can cause impaired walking, make it harder to perform activities of daily living, and worsen fatigue. The aim of treatment for spasticity in patients with MS is to decrease muscle tone enough that function improves, but not reduce it to the point that safety is decreased.
  • Baclofen is supportive therapy (rather than a disease-modifying drug) for MS and can be administered either orally or intrathecally via a pump.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 384

questions.text: An 18-year-old otherwise healthy female passed away due to massive hepatic necrosis 5 days after she underwent general anesthesia to repair a fractured femur. Which of the following is a general anesthetic most likely responsible for her death?
questions.solution:
• The anesthetic responsible for her massive hepatic necrosis (MHN) is the general anesthetic Halothane. Halothane causes Halothane Hepatitis in 1:30000 cases worldwide.
  • The mechanism of its function is still unknown. It does have a high blood solubility and its induction is slower than say nitrous oxide which has a low blood solubility.
  • It has a low minimum alveolar concentration (potency = 1/MAC) thus a high potency. Its physiological effects include myocardial depression, respiratory depression, and increase cerebral blood flow. A severe although rare side effect is MHN.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 406

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman, Yashasvi has a history of schizophrenia. Currently, she reports auditory hallucinations, but her spouse states that her symptoms have improved with medication. However, the patient has repetitive lip-smacking behavior and occasionally sweeps her tongue across her lips. Which of the following is the most likely medication this patient was started on?
questions.solution:
• This patient with positive symptoms of Schizophrenia and now lip-smacking behavior likely has Tardive dyskinesia from the typical antipsychotic Haloperidol.
  • While the typical antipsychotics block dopamine receptors, the atypical antipsychotics have varying effects on serotonin and dopamine receptors. In general, the typical antipsychotics are used for patients with positive symptoms but can be associated with extrapyramidal side effects.
  • Early on in the first few hours of use, this may result in acute dystonia. In the first several days, symptoms can include akathisias. In the first few weeks, patients develop bradykinesia. Finally, with long-term use of several months, patients can develop tardive dyskinesia, which is characterized by abnormal facial movements. The atypical antipsychotics have fewer extrapyramidal side effects.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 472

questions.text: A 45-year-old female, Sunidhi complained of shortness of breath along with profuse sweating and high BP. She was prescribed Phenelzine after failing treatment with first-line antidepressant therapy. What must she have been exposed to that led to such a dramatic side effect?
questions.solution:
• A patient presenting with a hypertensive crisis while on a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor most likely consumed tyramine-containing food (includes wine and cheese).
  • MAOIs are often secondary or tertiary therapeutics after selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) and tricyclic antidepressants (TCA) fail to elucidate a response from a patient suffering from depression.
  • They act by inhibiting amine neurotransmitters in the central nervous system and can also be used in anxiety and hypochondriasis. In addition to avoiding tyramine, patients on MAOIs must not take SSRIs, TCAs, and St. John's Wort to prevent serotonin syndrome.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 482

questions.text: An experimental infusible drug, X729, is currently being studied to determine its pharmacokinetics. The drug was found to have a half-life of 1.5 hours and is eliminated by first order kinetics. What is the minimum number of hours required to reach a steady state concentration of >90%?
questions.solution:
• The minimum number of hours required to reach a steady state concentration of >90% is 6 hours (4 half-lives).
  • A drug infused at a constant rate reaches about 94% of steady state concentration after 4 half-lives when it is eliminated by first order kinetics.
  • A simplified example is as follows: if compound Y (half-life of 1 hour) was infused at 100 mg/hr, then after 1 hour, 50% or 50 mg of the drug would be left in circulation.
  • In the next hour, another 100 mg would be infused and a total of 150 mg (100 mg infused + 50 mg from the first hour) would have circulated, but since another hour or half-life has passed the total amount remaining in circulation would be 75 mg or 75% of the infusible rate.
  • The calculation is similar for the next two hours where it will reach 93.75% of the steady state concentration by the fourth hour.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 40

questions.text:
An investigator wants to make sure that the plasma concentration of a drug Z in a patient is 15 mg/L and he knows the following drug characteristics.
Bioavailability: 50%
Drug half-life: 2 hours
Volume of distribution: 14.3 liters
Which of the following represents the maintenance dose that should be given to this patient every 8 hours?
questions.solution:
• The hourly maintenance dose can be calculated by multiplying the concentration by the clearance and dividing by bioavailability. This value is then multiplied by the number of hours to get the correct answer, which is 1200 milligrams.
  • The equation to calculate the maintenance dose of a drug is M = Cp x Cl/F, where M is the maintenance dose, Cp is the plasma concentration, Cl is the clearance, and F is the bioavailability of the drug.
  • Clearance is not provided directly; however, it can be calculated from the equation (Cl = 0.7 x Vd/t) where Vd is the volume of distribution and t is the half-life of the drug. In this case, the clearance is 0.7 x 14.3 L/2 hours = 5 L/hour.
  • The maintenance dose is therefore 15 mg/L x 5 L/hour/0.5 = 150 mg/hour. If doses are given every 8 hours, then this value needs to be multiplied by 8 to yield 1200 milligrams per dose.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 41

questions.text: Scientists are developing a new NSAID for osteoarthritis. Their hope is that the new drug will have a higher potency but the same efficacy as Ibuprofen in the hope of minimizing gastrointestinal side effects. If ibuprofen is curve C in the figure provided, which of the following would be the curve for the new drug based on the scientists' specifications? The desired therapeutic effect in patients is represented by the dashed line Y.
questions.solution:
• A drug that has the same efficacy but a higher potency than curve C would be further left on the graph with the same height on the y axis. This is represented by curve A.
  • Potency is the amount of a drug needed to produce a given effect and is largely determined by the affinity of the drug for its receptor and the number of available receptors.
  • The scientists wish to develop a drug that would have the same therapeutic effect at a lower dose, representing a new drug with higher potency than ibuprofen.
  • This would represent a curve that is shifted to the left on the figure provided. Potency is typically represented by the EC50, or the effective concentration at which 50% of the maximal effect is achieved.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 63-64

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman, Anupama presents to the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain. She is oriented to person but is slow to answer questions and cannot name her location. Her urine culture was positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrites. She was prescribed appropriate treatments. On follow-up, she complains of a new rash. In the past few days she has noticed that her skin becomes very red and more easily sunburns. Per the patient, her symptoms have resolved and her initial infection has cleared. Which of the following antibiotics was most likely prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient in the question suffers from a urinary tract infection (UTI) and exhibits photosensitivity, which is a common side effect of sulfonamides, including trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
  • Drug-induced photosensitivity is a common medication side effect, most often observed with sulfonamides, amiodarone, and tetracyclines. Photosensitivity can range in severity from mild redness to severe bullae formation and blistering. Fitzpatrick type I-II (or lighter skinned individuals) are more likely to experience this side effect. This sensitivity should subside after the offending drug is removed, or the course is completed as in this case.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 759

questions.text: A 64-year-old man, Gandhi is brought with a 2-hour history of diarrhea and vomiting. He says that he felt fine in the morning, but noticed that he was salivating, sweating, and feeling nauseated on the way home from his work. Physical exam reveals miosis, rhinorrhea, wheezing, and tongue fasciculations. Which of the following treatments would most likely be effective for this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient with diarrhea, vomiting, sweating, salivation, miosis, wheezing, and tongue fasciculations most likely experienced organophosphate poisoning and should be treated with atropine.
  • Organophosphates are a class of chemical agents that inhibit acetylcholinesterase, which cause increased acetylcholine activity. These compounds are found in nerve gas, insecticides, and herbicides among other industrial agents.
  • Poisoning with these agents presents with the DUMBBELSS symptoms: Diarrhea, Urination, Miosis, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Excitation of systems, Lacrimation, Sweating, and Salivation. The syndrome is usually diagnosed clinically and can be treated with the cholinergic inhibitor atropine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 122

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the ED with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and hematemesis after ingesting large quantities of a drug. Which of the following pairs a drug overdose with the correct antidote for this scenario?
questions.solution:
• This question assesses your knowledge of toxicology with a common poisoning vignette. The correct pairing of drug to antidote is iron to deferoxamine.
  • The patient's presentation suggests acute iron poisoning. Initial symptoms reflect the corrosive effects of iron on the gastrointestinal tract, including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and (sometimes) GI bleeding.
  • Some present with shock or coma. In acute iron poisoning, the patient may paradoxically feel better for a brief period. Deferoxamine is a specific chelator for ferric iron (Fe3+).
  • The chelation forms a water-soluble compound that is excreted via the kidneys. It can cause hypotension, so fluids must be replenished quickly in this patient for both the symptoms and for the antidote's side effect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 966

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman, Manjolika presents with severe pain of her first MTP joint. This pain started acutely, and she describes the pain as sharp. On examination, her right first MTP joint appears warm, swollen, erythematous, and exquisitely painful to the touch. After resolution of this acute episode, the patient is started on prophylactic therapy. One month later on follow-up, she is found to have pancytopenia. Which of the following describes the mechanism of the drug most likely prescribed in this case?
questions.solution:
• This patient with an acutely painful first MTP joint most likely has gout and was treated with a xanthine oxidase inhibitor. These drugs increase levels of azathioprine (used for treatment of inflammatory bowel disease) when used concurrently and can result in pancytopenia.
  • Gout is a cause of joint pain that results from deposition and subsequent inflammation of sodium urate crystals.
  • One major mechanism for preventing gout flare-ups is competitive inhibition of the xanthine oxidase enzyme. This enzyme is responsible for production of urate, so drug inhibitors lead to decreased circulating levels of this substance.
  • Since xanthine oxidase is also involved in the processing of some immunosuppressive drugs such as azathioprine and 6-mercaptopurine, concurrent administration of these drugs may lead to increased accumulation of the immunosuppressants. A toxicity of azathioprine, often used to treat inflammatory bowel disease, is pancytopenia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 233

questions.text: A 12-hour-old newborn is urgently transferred to NICU because he is found to be cyanotic and appears blue in all four extremities. On physical exam, the infant is found to have slanted eyes, a flattened head, a large tongue, and a single palmar crease bilaterally. Furthermore, a single, loud S2 murmur is appreciated in this patient. Radiography shows a large oblong-shaped heart shadow. Based on this presentation, he was started. The substance that was most likely administered in this case also has which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
• This patient most likely has transposition of the great vessels and was administered prostaglandin-E1 (PGE1) to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus. PGE1 has the additional effect of general vascular vasodilation.
  • Prostaglandins are a collection of inflammatory signals produced from arachidonic acid by cyclooxygenase enzymes.
  • Each prostaglandin has a unique set of activities based on the end organs that have receptors for that signal. PGE1, in particular, has an effect on vascular smooth muscle. In general, it has a vasodilatory effect that also prevents the closure of unneeded vessels.
  • Clinically, this aspect of PGE1 behavior is used to prevent the premature obliteration of a patent ductus arteriosus in newborns with ductal-dependent congenital heart disease. One such disease is transposition of the great vessels.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 199-201

choices.text: Facial drooping of the entire left face
Lower extremity clonus and muscle atrophy
Painful, unilateral lower extremity swelling with dyspnea

questions.text: Which of the following would have been a contraindication to the use of succinylcholine?
questions.solution:
• Rapid sequence intubation is used in emergency medicine for intubation of uncomplicated patients. One component is the neuromuscular blocking agent, which is either non-depolarizing or depolarizing. There are a variety of non-depolarizing agents (e.g., rocuronium and tubocurarine) that block the depolarization of the motor end plate.
  • However, the fastest and preferred agent is the only depolarizing agent, succinylcholine, which leads to continued depolarization and eventual unresponsiveness of the motor end plate. Hyperkalemia is a side effect of succinylcholine because of the efflux of potassium ions secondary to muscle depolarization.
  • Thus, any conditions that predispose to hyperkalemia (e.g., stroke, burns, denervation neuromuscular disease, rhabdomyolysis, and prolonged total body immobilization) are absolute contraindications; the mechanism of action is due to the upregulation of acetylcholine receptors. Another key side effect is malignant hyperthermia, which causes hyperthermia, sympathetic activity, and rigidity. It is managed by sedation, cooling, and Dantrolene.

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 373

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with a pulse of 32/min and BP 80/40 mmHg. She was found with an empty bottle of propranolol that was taken from her grandmother. Her vital signs do not improve despite IV fluids and oxygen. Which of the following is a first-line treatment for overdose?
questions.solution:
• Beta-blocker toxicity results in symptomatic bradycardia and hypotension. First-line antidote is glucagon.
  • Glucagon increases blood glucose and relaxes smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Glucagon has positive inotropic and chronotropic effects similar to those of beta-adrenergic agonists, but is believed to work by possibly bypassing the beta-adrenergic receptor site.
  • Glucagon works by binding of the specific extracellular glucagon receptors, thus leading to activation of cardiac adenylate cyclase and increasing cAMP concentrations.

Uses of Glucagon

  1. Hypoglycaemia Use of glucagon to counteract insulin/ oral hypoglycaemic drug induced hypoglycaemia is only an expedient measure for the emergency, and must be followed by oral glucose/sugar given repeatedly till the blood glucose level stabilizes. It may not work if hepatic glycogen is already depleted.
  2. Cardiogenic shock Glucagon may be used to stimulate the heart in β adrenergic blocker treated patients. However, action is not very marked.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 304

questions.text: A 35-year-old taxi driver presents to his physician with complaints of itchy, watery eyes and excessive sneezing that have become more severe with the change of the seasons. He has previously taken an anti-Histamine drug with moderate relief of his symptoms, but it made him very drowsy. He asks to switch to a medication that will not cause drowsiness that may impair his driving. Which of the following medications would you prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Cetirizine is a drug in the class of second-generation antihistamines (H1 blockers), which are much less sedating than the first-generation H1 blockers.
  • H1 blockers work by reversibly inhibiting H1 histamine receptors and are used clinically for the relief of allergy symptoms and motion sickness.
  • The second-generation H1 blockers have decreased entry into the CNS (due to their lipophobic properties) compared to the first-generation H1 blockers, and thus are much less sedating and will produce less drowsiness as a side effect.
  • The second-generation H1 blockers include cetirizine, loratadine, and fexofenadine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 180
